metadata.title: Don’t relax yet: Dangerous leads in soccer | by Yorgos Askalidis | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Don’t relax yet: Dangerous leads in soccer
metadata.description: You hear game commentators say that “a 2–0 lead is the most dangerous lead there is” implying that the chances that you will lose (or at best draw the game) are maximized compared to other similar…

all_paragraphs: You hear game commentators say that “a 2–0 lead is the most dangerous lead there is” implying that the chances that you will lose (or at best draw the game) are maximized compared to other similar scorelines.

It’s an interesting theory. With “only” a 1–0 lead the leading team still knows that the opponents are only one goal away from tying the game and then potentially gaining the psychological edge. Hence the leading team is still on guard and protects the lead more efficiently. But a 2–0 lead seems pretty comfortable: even if the opponents score you’re still ahead. That’s why, the theory suggests, the team that holds the 2–0 lead are more prone than ever to be scored upon (again and again) and eventually lose the game.
Is there any statistical merit to the theory?

I used this Kaggle dataset — that includes detailed events from 9K games played in England, Germany, France, Italy and Spain’s domestic leagues in the seasons 2012 up to 2017 — to try and add some data perspective to the popular theory.

For each game in the dataset I got every goal scored and the side that scored it (home or away). I then generated every scoreline each game produced. For example, if a game ended 2–1, the scorelines that game produced might have been 1–0, then 2–0 and then 2–1. In the end of this process, there were 57 unique scorelines. Note that the scoreline 2–1 is different than the scoreline 1–2.

I then subtracted the two numbers that comprise the scoreline to generate the lead. A positive lead indicates that the home team is winning (e.g., scoreline is 2–1, lead of 1 goal) and a negative lead indicates that the away team is winning (e.g., 1–2, lead of -1 goal). In order to be able to analyze positive and negative leads together, I compared the lead with the final result and assigned a “win/draw/lose” from the perspective of the leading team. So if the scoreline at some point is 2–1 and the home team eventually won that’s a ‘win’ for the leading team, if the away team won that would be a ‘lose’ for the leading team.

An important note for the above methodology is that the same game can contribute multiple observations to our dataset, one for each distinct scoreline. As an illustrative example, if a team is leading 1–0 at one point of the game, then 2–0 and finally 2–1 at another point that contributes two observations of 1-goal lead and one observation of a 2-goal lead where the home team won.
Finally, note that this methodology considers every possible scoreline within each game except draws.
Here’s the distribution of results for the leading team as a function of how big the lead is.

Contrary to what the theory suggests (but probably not surprisingly) we see that the higher your lead is the higher your chances of winning the game! Teams that have a 2-goal lead are 94% likely to win the game compared to “only” 72% likelihood of winning the game with a 1-goal lead. Having a 3-goal lead pretty much guarantees winning the game (99.1% probability). There is only one instance of a team leading by 3 goals and losing the game: A game between Lecce and Milan in the 2011–2012 season for the Italian “Serie A” league, where Lecce was leading 3–0 at halftime but Milan came back and won the game 3–4.
To get an understanding of the sample size of each bar in Figure 1 here’s how many times each lead was observed. Note that the same lead can be observed multiple times in the same game.

We can go one level deeper in our analysis and break down the probability distribution of results depending on the lead for the home and away team, i.e., compare the probability of winning the game when you’re leading the game by 2 goals as the home team and the away team.

Again, we see that the larger the lead the more likely you are to win the game both as the home as well as the away team. We also notice that the chances of winning the game are slimmer if you’re the away team compared to a home team with the same lead. This makes sense if we consider that the home team has their fans’ backing and hence might be more likely to make a comeback than an away team. A home team with a 1-goal lead is 76% likely to win the game whereas an away team with the same lead is 66% likely to win the game. The probabilities of winning the game with a 2-goal lead are 95% for the home team and 91% for the away. With a 3-goal lead the probabilities of victory are 99% and 98.5%.
There is no recorded draw or loss for a team leading by 4 goals.

OK, so no matter how we look at it, a 2–goal lead is much safer than a 1–goal lead, but can the theory that “a 2–0 lead is the most dangerous lead” get any statistical backing if we truly only consider 2–0 (or 0–2) scorelines and compare them to 1–0 (or 0–1) scorelines?

A team is substantially more likely to win the game if they are 2–0 ahead compared to if they are “just” 1–0 ahead. They are also virtually guaranteed to win the game if they are 3–0 up (Although, I’m sure 2005 Champions League final Milan will beg to differ).

So a statistical analysis of about 9K games across some of Europe’s biggest leagues (England, France, Germany, Italy and Spain) revealed no merit to the theory that a 2–0 lead is the most dangerous lead. The data suggest that the larger the lead the safer the team is.
Can the theory find any support in other sports? Or maybe electronic soccer (PES and FIFA)?
